qas.question: What type of orthography did Old Czech lack?
Why aren't some sound clusters used in modern Czech?
How did old Czech allow some complex consonant clusters to be pronounced?
What type of phenomenon is Havlik's law?
What law began in Old Czech?
What kind of alphabet was in Proto-Slavic?
What did Proto-Slavic have that no longer exists?
How did Proto-Slavic let complex consonant clusters to be pronounced?
What kind of orthography was missing from Proto-Slavic?

context: While Old Czech had <b6_0>a basic alphabet<b6_0/> from which a general set of orthographical correspondences was drawn, it did not have a <a0_0><b9_0>standard<b9_0/><a0_0/> orthography. It also contained <b7_0>a number of sound clusters<b7_0/> which <a1_0>no longer exist<a1_0/>; allowing ě (/jɛ/) after soft consonants, which has since shifted to e (/ɛ/), and allowing complex consonant clusters to be pronounced <a2_0><b8_0>all at once<b8_0/><a2_0/> rather than syllabically. A <a3_0>phonological<a3_0/> phenomenon, <b5_0>Havlik's law<b5_0/> (which began in Proto-Slavic and took various forms in other Slavic languages), appeared in Old Czech; counting backwards from the end of a clause, <a4_0>every odd-numbered<a4_0/> yer was vocalized as a vowel, while the other yers disappeared.
